title: What made John Lennon's voice so unique? - Quora

response.answer_text: John Lennon not only used different vocal techniques from song to song, he changed the way he sang within each song. Here are a few examples to show you what I mean. John’s fairly high, bright “head” voice made him easy to hear and understand on the radio, and the many nights singing in Hamburg nightclubs gave his voice power. On “I Wanna Hold Your Hand,” he starts off within normal speaking range, but strong enough to cut through the driving beat. His voice goes lower, almost naughty, for the words, “I think you understand.” Then he goes back up to normal range before hitting the almost feminine higher notes, “…hold your hand.” John changes his tone throughout the following lines, where he sings the title twice with a flourish, somewhat showy but also reassuring. Less talented vocalists would sing the song as simply happy lines, but in a short period of time John has been alternately vulnerable and brazen, while always in control of the story. He’s not singing “at” the song. You feel that he is telling a real story and connecting with the listener. Another great example of John using the top and bottom of his range is on “Just Like Starting Over.” The ballad “Girl” presents John as a worldly guy telling us about a woman he desires but who is frustrating him. His voice is sharp, nasal, and clinical, as if he’s going to verbally pick the girl apart. “She promises the earth to me…,” but he suddenly turns tender with his breathy voice, “…and I believe her.” The one-word chorus is a lustful sigh - “Ah, girl…” - followed by a dirty breath in. He sounds even more angry at the girl in the bridge (“She’s the kind of girl who puts you down when friends are there…”), but soon he works himself up into passion as he repeats, “She’s cool, ooh, ooh,…,” before releasing again into the sighs of, “Girl…” You can hear a more explosive example of this alternating tension in the song “I’m So Tired.” John had conflicting feelings about his fame. Sometimes he wanted the ability to disappear, to blend in with the crowd, but other times he felt he needed to use his platform to make big statements. This inner conflict came to a head on his solo song, “God.” He sounds conversational, but his words are the beginning of his big statement, “God is a concept by which we measure our pain.” He then says, “I’ll say it again,” and sure enough, to underline his theme, he repeats the line. From here he gets increasingly insistent, his voice torn and worn, as he casts away his mysticism and idols — “I don’t believe in magic, I don’t believe in I Ching,…” until he says, with gentle force but with the scratch of well-earned wisdom, “I don’t believe in Beatles.” His voice is gentle as a feather throughout the last section, “I was the Walrus, but now I’m John…the dream is over.” Whether or not you feel John was justified in his feeling of self-importance, he drew you into his world. It’s what makes “Beautiful Boy” an astonishingly intimate song. Even more than his song-writing skills, it was John’s ability turn bare all through his voice is what made his so loved by his fans.

What makes anyone’s voice unique? Look at people like Joe Cocker or Leon Russell as well as many singers. Everyone is born with a voice of their own, some are very generic and sound like many other singers while some are blessed with a voice that is uniquely their own. As already mentioned John hated the sound of his own voice and constantly had George Martin add effects to his tracks. He even used a Leslie cabinet on Tomorrow Never Knows and still his voice comes through as John Lennon. Even though he constantly tried to cover up his voice it was easy to tell who was singing. This was even more apparent as he got older. I have been a singer for more than 40 years and I too hated my voice and tried to sing a cover song trying to sound like the original artist. When I sang songs I wrote I would try to use a voice that was not really mine as well. Our lead guitarist finally said just use your own voice and so in practice i did and he told me that he liked my voice much better than the fake voices I had been using. I think this is common for many singers and John was no exception. The slightly nasal sound and the accent as well as the way he approached a song made his voice not only unique but memorable. While Paul had a smoother and more melodic voice John’s voice was always edgy and in your face.

Listening to the Beatles now after all these years as a professional musician I think it’s largely in the timing. It seems to me their music was vocal driven - even the drums accompanied the rhythmic drive that came from the vocals, especially Lennon’s. Nowadays all music is drum or bass driven, and nearly always the vocals are added last. This means the vocals have to work around the inflexibility of a pre-recorded rhythm track. This is particularly apparent whenever you hear the music in the background, say in a shop or somewhere. The fidelity of the sound doesn’t really compare to modern recordings, and in that situation you might not be able to hear the bass at all, and no more than a sizzle from the hi hat - yet it’s the rhythm of the vocals that give it that edge and still renders their music supreme. The other particular quality that was always extraordinary about Lennon was how well his voice blended with McCartney’s, even though their voices were very different. On early tracks like ‘Misery’, when they sang together they almost sounded like one person double tracked.

The most unique thing about John Lennon's voice is the versatility of his voice, his voice is more versatile than some people think. It is true that John's voice sounds rather nasal and his voice range is rather limited compared to Paul McCartney, but his voice is still versatile. John could do any other styles of vocal such as primal scream style vocal, psychedelic style vocal, ballad style vocal, rock n roll style of vocal, and even pop style vocal.

Other than natural, he doubled almost everything he sang, and put what came to be known as a “gating” effect on his voice. George Martin said he was simply amazed at a how well Lennon could double a recorded performance. Incidentally, Lennon was well known to HATE the sound of his voice. Funny, the mind. He was most definitely one of the best rock singers to ever live.

What I appreciate in John’s singing is just the chill he can give with the right inflection, whether it’s his nasty Rock voice or the creapy, whispy aspect. It’s just got a charisma that clearly inspired Paul and of course that just kept upping the anti. The one thing no one mentions is his willingness, even in his own songs, to take on harmony sections that don’t feature him singing the melody. “If I Fell” is one of the greatest harmonic undipinnings for a song he wrote.

“So I lit a fire isn’t it good Norwegian wood?” His cutting humor, sarcasm and biting wit come through in his expression. So he has this wise-ass attitude, coupled with years of exercise/practice/experience yelling out the words over insufficient PA, which made his voice quite powerful, as well. Power plus attitude equals unique. Add to that as a Lucky Strike Extra - this is true for all four mop tops - the Liverpudlian Scouse of the time.

John Lennon was an artist who used every tool in his voice box to express a feeling in the moment. I find his “Twist and shout,” “Mother” and “Come together” to be his most impressive full throttle songs, whereas “Beautiful boy” and “Imagine” show a softer side. Regardless of the song, it’s interesting how he uses different inflections, tones, energy, etc. to drive the point home. His isn’t a typically beautiful voice, but it gets the job done, and maybe that’s the most important thing.

His fame mostly. Maybe his strong British accent, which you can hear in his singing more then most British singers added some nice color and style, but for the most part, his voice wasn’t particularly any prettier or amazing then any other good, professional singer. Sort of “average-good”, not amazing, honestly. If you are interested in training your voice and growing stronger as a singer, check out my program out at Udemy. Respectfully,… Become a Great Singer: Your Complete Vocal Training System
He has a unique vocal chord condition: “TWIN FLAME RESONANCE” , which sounds like TWO PEOPLE SINGING. 🌀 We both have it. 🀄🙏
Every one has a unique voice.
